fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An event structure is defined to be triple {\mathopen {}\left (E,\mathsf {Con}_{E}, \leq _E\right )\mathclose {}} where E is a partial order of events partially ordered by the causal dependency relation \leq _E, and \mathsf {Con}_{E}\subseteq \mathcal {P}_{\mathit {fin}}{\mathopen {}\left (E\right )\mathclose {}} specifies when a finite subset of E is consistent, satisfying the following laws:

html:ol.html:li: every downset of E is finite;
any subset of a consistent subset is consistent;
for any consistent subset x\in \mathsf {Con}_{E} and e\leq e' with e'\in x, we have x\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{e\right \}\mathclose {}}\in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The definition of event structure only speaks of finite consistent subsets; these are extended to arbitrary subsets as follows.

fr:title.text: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A subset x\subseteq E of an event structure is said to be consistent when any finite subset of x lies in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A configuration of an event structure E is defined to be a consistent, downward-closed subset of E. We will write \mathcal {C}_{E} for the set of all configurations of E and \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} for the set of finite configurations of E.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A rigid morphism of event structures {E}\xrightarrow {{f}}{E'} is a monotone function on events that preserves finite configurations and is locally injective in the sense that for any finite configuration x\in \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} and events e_1,e_2\in x such that fe_1 = fe_2, we have e_1=e_2.

I have not checked whether the appropriate structure identity principle holds for the (pre)category of event structures and rigid morphisms. If it does not hold, this would suggest that a new univalent definition of event structure is needed.

fr:title.text: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: 2010 25th Annual IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This paper establishes a bridge between presheaf models for concurrency and the more operationally-informative world of event structures. It concentrates on a particular presheaf category, consisting of presheaves over finite partial orders of events; such presheaves form a model of nondeterministic processes in which the computation paths have the shape of partial orders. It is shown how with the introduction of symmetry event structures represent all presheaves over finite partial orders. This is in contrast with plain event structures which only represent certain separated presheaves. Specifically a coreflection from the category of presheaves to the category of event structures with symmetry is exhibited. It is shown how the coreflection can be cut down to an equivalence between the presheaf category and the subcategory of graded event structures with symmetry. Event structures with strong symmetries are shown to represent precisely all the separated presheaves. The broader context and specific applications to the unfolding of higher-dimensional automata and Petri nets, and weak bisimulation on event structures are sketched.
These notes are inspired and in large part derived from my reading of Staton and Winskel’s paper on event structures with symmetry.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An event structure is defined to be triple {\mathopen {}\left (E,\mathsf {Con}_{E}, \leq _E\right )\mathclose {}} where E is a partial order of events partially ordered by the causal dependency relation \leq _E, and \mathsf {Con}_{E}\subseteq \mathcal {P}_{\mathit {fin}}{\mathopen {}\left (E\right )\mathclose {}} specifies when a finite subset of E is consistent, satisfying the following laws:

html:ol.html:li: every downset of E is finite;
any subset of a consistent subset is consistent;
for any consistent subset x\in \mathsf {Con}_{E} and e\leq e' with e'\in x, we have x\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{e\right \}\mathclose {}}\in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The definition of event structure only speaks of finite consistent subsets; these are extended to arbitrary subsets as follows.

fr:title.text: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Consistent subsets of an event structure

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A subset x\subseteq E of an event structure is said to be consistent when any finite subset of x lies in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A configuration of an event structure E is defined to be a consistent, downward-closed subset of E. We will write \mathcal {C}_{E} for the set of all configurations of E and \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} for the set of finite configurations of E.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A rigid morphism of event structures {E}\xrightarrow {{f}}{E'} is a monotone function on events that preserves finite configurations and is locally injective in the sense that for any finite configuration x\in \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} and events e_1,e_2\in x such that fe_1 = fe_2, we have e_1=e_2.

I have not checked whether the appropriate structure identity principle holds for the (pre)category of event structures and rigid morphisms. If it does not hold, this would suggest that a new univalent definition of event structure is needed.
An event structure is called elementary when every finite set of events is consistent.

A computation path is defined to be a finite elementary event structure; we define the category of computation paths to be the full subcategory of event structures and rigid maps spanned by computation paths.
A computation path is clearly same thing as a finite poset. A rigid morphism between computation paths corresponds, however, to a monomorphism of posets (not necessarily regular).

fr:title.text: Event structures and prime algebraic domains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Event structures and prime algebraic domains

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Event structures are the same thing as prime algebraic domains; on objects, this has been proved many times, but I could only find the correct notion of morphism in a paper of Abbes.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An event structure is defined to be triple {\mathopen {}\left (E,\mathsf {Con}_{E}, \leq _E\right )\mathclose {}} where E is a partial order of events partially ordered by the causal dependency relation \leq _E, and \mathsf {Con}_{E}\subseteq \mathcal {P}_{\mathit {fin}}{\mathopen {}\left (E\right )\mathclose {}} specifies when a finite subset of E is consistent, satisfying the following laws:

html:ol.html:li: every downset of E is finite;
any subset of a consistent subset is consistent;
for any consistent subset x\in \mathsf {Con}_{E} and e\leq e' with e'\in x, we have x\cup {\mathopen {}\left \{e\right \}\mathclose {}}\in \mathsf {Con}_{E}.

fr:link.title: On the expressivity of symmetry in event structures

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A rigid morphism of event structures {E}\xrightarrow {{f}}{E'} is a monotone function on events that preserves finite configurations and is locally injective in the sense that for any finite configuration x\in \mathcal {C}_{E}^{\mathit {fin}} and events e_1,e_2\in x such that fe_1 = fe_2, we have e_1=e_2.
Rijke defines an identity system on an element a:A to consist of a family of types \mathcal {I} over A equipped with the following data:

{I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (x:A\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod dependent function \beta _{\mathcal {I}}P : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{J_{\mathcal {I}}P\,p\,a\,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}} =_{P{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}} {p}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {I} be an identity system on an element a:A and let B be a family of types over A. A dependent identity system over \mathcal {I} on an element b:Ba in the family B consists of a family of types \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (x,q\right )\mathclose {}} over Bx for each x:A,q:\mathcal {I}x such that \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{I}\right )\mathclose {}} is equipped with the structure of an identity system on b : Ba. In particular, we have:

html:ol.html:li: for each family P over \mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{I}\right )\mathclose {}}, a dependent function J_{\mathcal {J}}P : \mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (y:Ba\right )\mathclose {}}}}\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (q:\mathcal {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod {J}{\mathopen {}\left (a,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {I}}\right )\mathclose {}}y\right )\mathclose {}}}}{P{\mathopen {}\left (y,q\right )\mathclose {}}} and a dependent function \beta _{\mathcal {J}}P:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (p:P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J_{\mathcal {J}}p\,b\,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}} =_{P{\mathopen {}\left (b,\mathsf {refl}_{\mathcal {J}}\right )\mathclose {}}} {p}.
